results.content:
Very thorough and covered everything I expected. But the instructor is so slow, so very... very... slow... to get the meat of how to build a chatbot, hence the 3 star rating.

Great for javascript beginners, tedious as hell for intermediate and above developers... But I do have a very good understanding now.

response.content: Slow is relative to your ability to grasp concepts. The course caters to all kinds of learners hence i have to maintain a speed that caters to individuals who need time to grasp concepts first since that is the only way . For fast learners you do have an option to speed up videos if you find them slow and time consuming.
response.content_html: Slow is relative to your ability to grasp concepts. The course caters to all kinds of learners hence i have to maintain a speed that caters to individuals who need time to grasp concepts first since that is the only way . For fast learners you do have an option to speed up videos if you find them slow and time consuming.

results.content: This is really an excellent course providing hands-on implementation for building state-of-the-art messaging interaction bots.  Utilizing Facebook messenger, Nodejs, api.ai, and wit.ai, complex interaction models are built including intents, entities and state management.  Sachin does an excellent job to introduce concepts and then demonstrating implementation details.  As an emerging technology, this is maybe one of the best overviews of how to build interactive chat bots.

response.content: Thank you so much for your kind review Scott. I'm so glad you liked the course.
response.content_html: Thank you so much for your kind review Scott. I'm so glad you liked the course.

results.content_html: This is really an excellent course providing hands-on implementation for building state-of-the-art messaging interaction bots. Utilizing Facebook messenger, Nodejs, api.ai, and wit.ai, complex interaction models are built including intents, entities and state management. Sachin does an excellent job to introduce concepts and then demonstrating implementation details. As an emerging technology, this is maybe one of the best overviews of how to build interactive chat bots.

results.content: The course so far is pretty rudimentary, but I've only just started. I will be most interested in the NLP processing when we get to it, especially how it differs from RegEx. I'm also interested in how state processing is handled to go beyond 1-to-1 input/response transactions.

response.content: Hello Kurt, thank you for your feedback. The regex chapter is a conceptual chapter and we move to NLP using Wit and later Dialogflow after that. If there is anything that you find amiss in the course, feel free to write to me directly and I’ll be happy to help you out personally. I’ll be adding more sections in the coming weeks and months as this course evolves.
response.content_html: Hello Kurt, thank you for your feedback. The regex chapter is a conceptual chapter and we move to NLP using Wit and later Dialogflow after that. If there is anything that you find amiss in the course, feel free to write to me directly and I’ll be happy to help you out personally. I’ll be adding more sections in the coming weeks and months as this course evolves.

results.content: The course is good and the instructor is very helpful and good at explaining the concepts during the course lectures. As I don't have the Nodejs background, I feel bit scared to code the logic as it is bit heavy and not easy to grasp and understand. Had there been some introductory lectures on main Nodejs concepts, it would been much better.

response.content: Thank you Praveen for your kind review. Well, NodeJS is a listed pre-requisite for this course and since it is a completely different topic, it makes no sense to include even the most basic of introductions, in this course. I do have a NodeJS course as well, and I'll be happy to extend a coupon to you.

results.content: Great course! Sachin, the instructor, has done a great job with this amazing course. Although some lectures are a bit outdated, I think this is perfectly admissible in this fast growing world. Trust me, if you are looking for a good (and probably the best) course about chatbots, this is yours. The lectures about API.AI and WIT.AI are really really amazing!

response.content: Thank you so much for your kind review Lucas. You nailed the fact that it is virtually impossible to keep pace with tech. growing at the speed of thought. However, it is my endeavour to keep this course updated and the same happens at preset intervals throughout the year.

results.content: Sachin did a great job on this course. Not only are you exposed to many chatbot relevant platforms and technologies, but he shows you a few different approaches to creating and deploying your own chatbots without being dogmatic on "the way" to do things. A great course for anyone interested.

response.content: Thank you so much Gregory!

results.content_html: Awesome course! I learned a great deal about creating Chatbots and am ready to build a few of my own. Thanks Sachin!

results.content: Content is explained well, and seems fairly up to date. If I could change one thing so far, it would be to drop the regex chatbot section. Seems like it's mostly included as a straw man, for sake of comparison with modern AI-based methods. But I think we're all here to learn the modern way, not the old-school way.

response.content:
Thank you for your kind feedback, Nathan.  

The regex bot section is a conceptual section, designed to get your hands dirty with elementary pattern matching, which is later handled by NLU services. It is not meant to be treated as a production example. A lot of bots are purely rule-based and this section is only meant to deliver a conceptual firm ground to that effect. The rest of the course, then graduates to the use of AI based techniques. 

Jumping straight to the magic box, isn't something that I personally endorse as a good learning approach.
response.content_html:
Thank you for your kind feedback, Nathan.

The regex bot section is a conceptual section, designed to get your hands dirty with elementary pattern matching, which is later handled by NLU services. It is not meant to be treated as a production example. A lot of bots are purely rule-based and this section is only meant to deliver a conceptual firm ground to that effect. The rest of the course, then graduates to the use of AI based techniques.

Jumping straight to the magic box, isn't something that I personally endorse as a good learning approach.

Seems like it's mostly included as a straw man, for sake of comparison with modern AI-based methods. But I think we're all here to learn the modern way, not the old-school way.

results.content: going toooooo  fast, hard to follow  for beginners  and  please  upload  code  and  give detailed  explanations  about tools,  80%  users  still   uses windows ,  please  add  windows  commands  , may be  please   add  windows  environment  setup  courses

response.content:
Hi Venkat, one of the benefits of online courses is that you can watch videos again and again until the concept is firmly established. The course contains all the code that is shown at the end of every section. I personally don't use Windows and the setup isn't different either. The prerequisites of the course make it abundantly clear that you should be comfortable with using Node.js. Additionally I'm not using any Mac specific commands other than occasionally creating a file, listing files etc, all of which is pretty basic and you should be comfortable with equivalents on Windows. Besides Node.js, I'm using VSCode as my editor. You're free to use any code editor of your choice.

It appears you're not comfortable with Node.js, which is mandatory for taking this course. Please feel free to discuss with me.
response.content_html:
Hi Venkat, one of the benefits of online courses is that you can watch videos again and again until the concept is firmly established. The course contains all the code that is shown at the end of every section. I personally don't use Windows and the setup isn't different either. The prerequisites of the course make it abundantly clear that you should be comfortable with using Node.js. Additionally I'm not using any Mac specific commands other than occasionally creating a file, listing files etc, all of which is pretty basic and you should be comfortable with equivalents on Windows. Besides Node.js, I'm using VSCode as my editor. You're free to use any code editor of your choice.

It appears you're not comfortable with Node.js, which is mandatory for taking this course. Please feel free to discuss with me.

response.content: George, I'm always available to help you out whenever you're stuck. You'll be suprised to know that the Motion.ai section was recorded just a couple of weeks back and is quite updated. I would expect you to write to me if you ever get stuck. Had you told me about it, I would've helped out. Lectures are updated from time to time,  and on a schedule. For other times, I'm available to each and every student personally, both on and off Udemy. So, write to me if you get stuck someplace.

response.content: Hi Rolando, the problem seems to be with the Udemy video player and a bad connection at your end, due to which the video adaptively degrades. This is a feature of the Udemy video player.  All videos have been recorded at full HD. And no zooms or scaling up has been used on code. Please consult Udemy support.
